Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents at 39 weeks of gestation with vaginal bleeding, having not received prenatal care. Previous deliveries include one cesarean section due to footling breech presentation and two vaginal deliveries.

Secondary_Symptoms: Severe bleeding from the external os

Abdominal_.Findings: Nontender abdomen, no contractions felt, fetus in vertex presentation

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the main component of pulmonary surfactant produced by type II pneumocytes in a premature infant requiring surfactant replacement therapy.

Patient_Actor.Demographics: Male infant, born at 27 weeks gestation
Patient_Actor.History: Born following premature rupture of membranes and precipitous labor to a G4P3 female. Steroids were not given due to the speed of delivery.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the initial management for a patient with shortness of breath and signs of heart failure.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath for the past 2 hours. He reports having a cough, cold, and fever for the last 3 days and has taken an over-the-counter cold preparation. His medical history includes hypertension and coronary artery disease for the last 7 years. His regular medications include aspirin and ramipril.

Secondary_Symptoms: Cough, cold, and fever for the last 3 days
Pitting edema bilaterally over the ankles and pretibial regions

Physical_Exam.Edema: Pitting edema bilaterally over the ankles and pretibial regions
Physical_Exam.Lung_Auscultation: Pulmonary crackles over lung bases bilaterally

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of anemia and fatigue in a pregnant patient presenting for elective cesarean delivery.

Patient_Actor.History: At 37+6 weeks of gestation, the patient presents for elective cesarean delivery. She reports increased fatigue over the past few weeks and has a past medical history of gestational hypertension, for which she has been taking an antihypertensive drug since week 24.

General_.Findings: Generalized pallor

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the cause of hemolytic anemia in a child with a recent history of gastrointestinal symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the physician with a 1-day history of passing small quantities of dark urine. Two weeks prior, he experienced fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, which were treated with oral antibiotics.

Physical_.Findings: Pale conjunctivae and scleral icterus

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the risk factors associated with the development of squamous cell carcinoma of the penis.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with redness and foul-smelling discharge from his penis. He is not married and denies sexual activity, trauma, or any associated fevers or chills. Initial work-up for sexually-transmitted diseases was negative, leading to a biopsy and imaging.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Redness and foul-smelling discharge from the penis

Biopsy.Findings: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain likely associated with food intake during a picnic.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain that started 2 hours ago after attending a picnic where he consumed a cheese sandwich and potato salad. He reports that several friends who attended the picnic also have similar symptoms. His medical history includes well-controlled celiac disease on a gluten-free diet and a prior appendectomy last year.

Secondary_Symptoms: Recent food intake at a picnic

Correct_Diagnosis: A toxin produced by a gram-positive, catalase-positive bacteria

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage the treatment for a burn injury following an electrical fire.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department after an electrical fire in her apartment. She left the room immediately when the fire started and has a burn on her right forearm.

Secondary_Symptoms: Intact pulses and sensations in all extremities
No evidence of soot in the mouth

Burn_.Findings: Dry, white, and leathery texture burn on right forearm

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of fatigue and thyroid dysfunction in a patient with increasing fatigue and weight gain.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a four-month history of increasing fatigue, occasional constipation, and a 15-pound weight gain. She is otherwise healthy, takes no medications, and has never been pregnant.

Physical_.Findings: Skin is dry and cracked. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally.

Biopsy.Findings: Lymphocytic infiltrate with germinal center formation

Correct_Diagnosis: Lymphocytic infiltrate with germinal center formation

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the cause of jaundice in a 3-day-old infant presenting with elevated unconjugated bilirubin.

Patient_Actor.History: First child from a healthy pregnancy, born on time via spontaneous vaginal delivery with no complications. Family history includes a maternal aunt who died as an infant of unknown causes.

General_.Findings: Healthy appearance except for jaundice

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of left lower extremity pain and swelling in a pregnant patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 2-day history of left lower extremity pain and swelling.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Left lower extremity pain and swelling
Secondary_Symptoms: Tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg

Physical_.Findings: Tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg with erythema and induration

Ultrasound_Findings.Findings: Vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of hypercalcemia and gastrointestinal symptoms in a patient with a recent change in diet and exercise.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with constipation, abdominal pain, and decreased appetite for the past 2 months. She has started a new diet and has been exercising 2 hours daily for several months to lose weight. Her medical history includes hypertension and hypothyroidism. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications are hydrochlorothiazide, a multivitamin, and levothyroxine, along with over-the-counter supplements taken with each meal.

Abdominal_.Findings: Soft abdomen with decreased bowel sounds

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the cause of profuse diarrhea and vomiting in a child with recent travel history.

Patient_Actor.History: The child has been experiencing profuse diarrhea and vomiting for the past 2 days. He was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery, is up to date on vaccines, and is meeting all developmental milestones. There is no significant past medical history. The family recently traveled to India to visit relatives.

General_.Findings: The child appears unwell with poor skin turgor and dry oral mucosa.

Abdominal_.Findings: Abdomen is sensitive to shallow and deep palpation.

Lung_.Findings: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of bloody vaginal discharge and exophytic cervical mass in a patient with an IUD.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a mild bloody vaginal discharge for the past 4 months, which worsens after sexual intercourse. She has also noted an unpleasant odor recently. She has a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and has had the same sexual partner for the past 15 years. A levonorgestrel-releasing IUD was inserted 4 years ago, and she has not had a gynecologic evaluation since then. Her past medical history includes treated Graves' disease with radioactive iodine ablation.

Gynecologic_.Findings: Deformed cervix with a 4-cm exophytic mass and necrotization arising from the posterior lip of the cervix; no vulvar or vaginal lesions; uterus not enlarged; no adnexal masses palpable.

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of acute leg weakness in a previously healthy 6-year-old female with a history of recent fever and no immunizations.

Patient_Actor.Demographics: 6-year-old female from a rural village in Afghanistan
Patient_Actor.History: Presented with leg weakness. Mother reports fever, fatigue, and headache a week prior that resolved. Patient has not received any immunizations since birth.

Neurological_.Findings: 1/5 strength in right hip and knee actions; 0/5 strength in left hip and knee actions; decreased tone in both lower extremities; intact sensation to touch, temperature, and vibration; absent patellar and Achilles reflexes bilaterally.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of vitamin D deficiency and its relation to the patient's pathologic fracture.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents for evaluation of vitamin D deficiency with possible osteomalacia. He had a pathologic fracture 3 weeks ago and was found to have dangerously low levels of vitamin D with normal serum calcium levels.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate respiratory symptoms and joint pain to determine the underlying cause.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 4-month history of dry cough and shortness of breath on exertion, along with recurrent pain, stiffness, and swelling in her wrist and left knee over the past 6 months. She has a history of two miscarriages at ages 24 and 28.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Dry cough and shortness of breath on exertion
Secondary_Symptoms: Recurrent pain, stiffness, and swelling in wrist and left knee
Annular hyperpigmented plaques on arms and neck
Fine inspiratory crackles over bilateral lower lung fields

Auscultation.Findings: Fine inspiratory crackles over bilateral lower lung fields

Skin_.Findings: Annular hyperpigmented plaques on arms and neck; ulcerations on the palate

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the physiological state of a patient found after prolonged dehydration and starvation.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was found in the wilderness after being lost for 2 days without food and water.

Correct_Diagnosis: Urine volume: decreased; urine osmolarity: increased; free water clearance: decreased; antidiuretic hormone (ADH): increased

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the cause of altered mental status and guide management in a patient with a history of chronic conditions.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presented with a change in behavior, observed by his wife who noted he seemed somnolent and unresponsive. His past medical history includes type II diabetes, obesity, osteoarthritis, and migraine headaches. Current medications are naproxen, insulin, atorvastatin, metformin, ibuprofen, omeprazole, and fish oil.

Neurological_Exam.Findings: Deferred due to the patient's condition (somnolent)

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and confirm the diagnosis of Goodpasture's disease in a patient presenting with renal and respiratory symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has facial swelling and blood in his urine for the last 3 days, along with weakness, malaise, and low-grade fevers persisting for the past 3 months.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Facial swelling and blood in urine

General_.Findings: Bilateral periorbital edema

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of altered mental status in a patient with chronic kidney disease and recent changes in cognition.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was admitted with confusion, lethargy, and memory issues. His mental state changed over the past few days, with intermittent normal behavior and episodes of hallucinations. He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease, managed with regular hemodialysis. No history of smoking, alcohol, or drug use.

Neurological_.Findings: Oriented only to person and place. Mini-mental state  (MMSE) score of 18/30; difficulty with arithmetic and recall. Nuchal rigidity absent. Muscle strength 5/5 bilaterally.

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of a severe, throbbing headache and manage acute symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a severe headache for the last 2 hours, which has been progressively worsening and aggravated by movement. He has had similar episodes in the past and usually takes acetaminophen and sleeps it off. No significant past medical history and no current medications.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Severe, throbbing headache on the left side
Secondary_Symptoms: Mild conjunctival injection in the left eye

Ocular_.Findings: Mild conjunctival injection in the left eye, normal intraocular pressure

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the cardiovascular signs associated with a history of injection drug use and suspected infective endocarditis.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of injection drug use and previous infective endocarditis. He has been experiencing shortness of breath and fatigue for several weeks, with difficulty climbing stairs and episodes of palpitations.

Cardiovascular_Exam.Findings: Carotid pulse shows rapid rise and fall

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of acute seizure in a postpartum woman with a history of gestational hypertension.

Patient_Actor.History: Six hours after giving birth to a healthy 3100 g girl, the patient experienced a sudden tonic-clonic seizure lasting 2 minutes. Prior to the seizure, she had been complaining of headache, blurry vision, and abdominal pain for an hour. Her pregnancy was complicated by gestational hypertension and iron deficiency anemia. Medications until birth included labetalol, iron supplements, and a multivitamin.

Secondary_Symptoms: Increased deep tendon reflexes (3+ with shortened relaxation phase)

Neurological_.Findings: Cranial nerves intact, normal muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes 3+

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the psychological impact of perceived skin issues and assess for underlying mental health disorders.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with severe acne and spots on her face that have persisted for 8 years, despite numerous creams and lotions. She spends several hours every morning using make-up to cover her skin issues and wishes to learn about cosmetic procedures.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Concern about skin problems and severe acne
Secondary_Symptoms: Reports of spending hours on make-up
Perceived need for improvement despite normal  findings

Vital_Signs.General_Appearance: Healthy-appearing, well-nourished female with normal complexion

Skin_.Findings: Minimal acne and sparse freckles on the nasal bridge

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of respiratory distress and chest tightness following nasal polyp removal under anesthesia.

Patient_Actor.History: Thirty minutes after surgical nasal polyp removal for refractory rhinitis, the patient developed retrosternal chest tightness and shortness of breath in the post-anesthesia care unit. The surgical course was uncomplicated and the patient was successfully extubated. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, hypertension, and sensitivity to aspirin. His daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. He has a significant smoking history of 20 pack-years.

Lung_.Findings: Bilateral wheezes and decreased breath sounds

ECG.Findings: No abnormalities noted

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the nerve affected in a pregnant patient presenting with bilateral numbness and tingling in the hands.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is healthy and has gained 35 lbs during pregnancy. She reports experiencing bilateral numbness and tingling in her palms, thumbs, index, and middle fingers for several weeks, which is worse at night. She also notes weakness in gripping objects.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Bilateral numbness and tingling in hands

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of severe abdominal pain and associated symptoms in a patient with a history of biliary colic.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with severe abdominal pain for several hours, cramp-like in nature, and has worsened over time. He has a history of episodic right upper abdominal pain after consuming fatty foods, radiating to the tip of the right scapula. No changes in bowel or bladder habits, and no weight loss. Past medical history includes diabetes and hypertension.

Abdominal_.Findings: Distended abdomen, diffusely tender

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of severe headaches, lightheadedness, and auditory symptoms in a young woman with elevated blood pressure.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with severe headaches and lightheadedness for 2 months, along with a 'swoosh' sound in the left ear for the past month. She has a history of allergic rhinitis and acne. Her sister is being treated for thyroid cancer. Medications include levocetirizine, topical clindamycin, and azelastine-fluticasone nasal spray.

Head_and_Neck_.Findings: Bruit on the left side of the neck

Skin_.Findings: Cystic acne over the face and back

Abdominal_.Findings: Soft and nontender abdomen with an abdominal bruit on the left side

Cardiac_.Findings: No murmurs, rubs, or gallops

Lung_.Findings: Clear to auscultation

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of anemia and jaundice in a patient with a history of aortic valve replacement surgery.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and brownish discoloration of the urine for the past 5 weeks. He has a significant past medical history of aortic valve replacement surgery 2 years ago.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Progressive fatigue and shortness of breath

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of infertility in a 28-year-old woman with physical  findings suggestive of a congenital anomaly.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. She has never been pregnant. Her husband has two children from a previous marriage. She has a history of a collarbone fracture from a skiing accident but otherwise has been healthy with no chronic conditions.

Secondary_Symptoms: Small vagina with no visible cervical canal

Pelvic_.Findings: Minimal pubic hair, suprapubic masses, small vagina with no cervical canal visible

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the causal organism of diarrhea and abdominal cramping in a patient with HIV and recent travel history.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 2-week history of diarrhea (up to 10 watery stools per day) and abdominal cramping. She has anorexia and nausea. She returned from a trip to Mexico 4 weeks ago, where she drank from spring water and went on hiking trips. She has been noncompliant with her HIV therapy and her last CD4+ T-lymphocyte count was 85/mm3.

Abdominal_.Findings: Soft abdomen with diffuse tenderness to palpation, no guarding or rebound tenderness

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of fatigue, fever, shortness of breath, and lymphadenopathy in a pediatric patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 2-week history of generalized fatigue, intermittent fever, and progressively worsening shortness of breath. She is brought to the physician by her mother.

Secondary_Symptoms: Hepatomegaly (liver palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin)

Physical_.Findings: Pallor, jugular venous distention, nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy, inspiratory stridor, liver palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of fever and abdominal pain in a patient with a history of chills and icterus.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a fever for the past 48 hours, accompanied by chills and increasing abdominal pain. The abdominal pain is constant, non-radiating, and rated as 4/10.

Secondary_Symptoms: Severe tenderness on palpation of the right hypochondrium

Abdominal_.Findings: Severe tenderness on palpation of the right hypochondrium

Ultrasound.Findings: Dilated bile duct and calculus in the bile duct

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the impact of lifestyle factors, specifically alcohol consumption, on sleep quality and patterns in a patient with insomnia.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents for a routine check-up. Reports lifelong trouble sleeping, with worsening difficulties in falling and staying asleep over the past few months. Experiences daytime fatigue and sleepiness without time to nap. Background includes essential hypertension treated with lisinopril.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of increased hunger, thirst, and urination in a 15-year-old male patient.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the physician by his mother due to concerns about a change in dietary habits, including constant hunger and thirst despite eating and drinking water excessively. Reports increased bathroom use.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying metabolic defect in a pediatric patient presenting with recurrent infections and an acute purulent lesion.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 3-day history of fever and lethargy. He has experienced more infections than expected since birth but has otherwise developed normally.

Secondary_Symptoms: Purulent, erythematous bump on left upper extremity

_Findings.Lesion: Purulent, erythematous bump on left upper extremity

Leukocyte_Test.Findings: Confirmed diagnosis based on clinical suspicion

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of severe lower abdominal pain and vomiting in a patient with a history of cholecystectomy.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 24-hour history of severe lower abdominal pain, two episodes of nonbloody vomiting, and inability to keep down food or fluids. She has not had a bowel movement since the day before. Medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis, with a cholecystectomy performed 5 years ago. She has a long history of smoking (one pack daily for 20 years). Current medications include chlorthalidone, atorvastatin, and naproxen.

Secondary_Symptoms: Inability to keep down food or fluids

Abdominal_.Findings: Soft abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds, moderate left lower quadrant tenderness, tender mass palpable on digital rectal , no guarding or rebound tenderness

Correct_Diagnosis: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of gradually worsening abdominal pruritus in an elderly patient without recent travel history.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 2-week history of gradually worsening abdominal pruritus. He is unsure if his skin has yellowed and carries an identification card without a photograph for comparison.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a patient with signs of liver failure and increasing confusion, likely due to viral hepatitis.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the emergency department by her husband due to increasing confusion for 3 days and yellowish discoloration of her eyes for the past 6 days. Medical history includes osteoarthritis. Current medications are acetaminophen and a vitamin supplement. Patient does not consume alcohol and uses intravenous cocaine occasionally.

Secondary_Symptoms: Tender liver palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin

Physical__Findings.Findings: Confusion, oriented only to person, scleral icterus, jaundice, flapping tremors, tender liver without splenomegaly

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of arthritis and rash in a patient with a recent viral illness.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 5-day history of pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists, and a nonpruritic generalized rash. She had fever and a runny nose 10 days ago that resolved without treatment. She is sexually active, uses condoms inconsistently, and works as an elementary school teacher.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Pain and stiffness in hands and wrists
Secondary_Symptoms: Stiffness worst in the morning, improving after 15-20 minutes of activity
Lacy macular rash over trunk and extremities
Swelling and tenderness of wrists, metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints

Joint_.Findings: Swelling, tenderness, and decreased range of motion of wrists and hand joints

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the physiological effects of epinephrine infusion and subsequent phenoxybenzamine administration on the autonomic nervous system.

Patient_Actor.History: The volunteer received an infusion of 40 ²5g of epinephrine over 5 minutes, followed by administration of phenoxybenzamine.

Secondary_Symptoms: Physiological changes in response to epinephrine and phenoxybenzamine

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the best choice of a second medication for a patient with type II diabetes mellitus seeking additional weight loss.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was initially diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus three months ago with an HbA1c of 8.8%. She was started on metformin, which was uptitrated to the maximum dose. Her body mass index (BMI) was 31 kg/m^2 at that time. She has been adherent to her medications, including atorvastatin and lisinopril, and has started a daily walking routine.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a pediatric patient presenting with a rash.

Patient_Actor.History: The mother brings the child to the pediatric clinic with concerns of a rash.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of recurrent falls and movement difficulties in an elderly patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of recurrent falls and has been slow in his movements, walking clumsily. He denies fever, vision problems, limb weakness, numbness, abnormal sensation in his limbs, trauma, or inability to pass urine. Past medical history is unremarkable, currently taking calcium and vitamin D supplements.

Secondary_Symptoms: Bilateral hand tremor, more pronounced on the left
Increased muscle tone in all 4 limbs
Small steps with decreased arm swinging
Difficulty in taking first few steps and changing directions

Neurological_Exam.Findings: Awake, alert, and oriented to time, place, and person; normal eye movements; increased muscle tone; normal deep tendon reflexes; MMSE score 26/30.

Correct_Diagnosis: Loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of altered mental status, ecchymoses, and respiratory symptoms in a patient with a productive cough and fever.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 3-day history of productive cough with purulent sputum, fever, and chills. He developed bloody vomiting, altered mental status, and multiple red spots (ecchymoses) all over the body.

Secondary_Symptoms: Crackles at the right lung base

Physical_.Findings: Ecchymoses on both lower extremities and crackles heard at the right lung base

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify and describe a congenital pancreatic anomaly following ERCP.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for evaluation of suspected biliary strictures, during which a congenital pancreatic anomaly was diagnosed.

Imaging.Findings: ERCP identified two ducts in the pancreas: a small ventral duct and a larger dorsal duct.

Correct_Diagnosis: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) scanning of the abdomen is the most sensitive non-invasive diagnostic technique for this condition

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the underlying cause of endocarditis in a patient with evidence of vegetations and initiate appropriate follow-up management.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was admitted with fever, chills, and rigor lasting 4 days, along with recent-onset fatigue. His past medical history is insignificant, and he consumes a can of beer every night.

Cardiac_.Findings: 2/6 apical pansystolic murmur

Echocardiogram.Findings: Evidence of vegetations over the mitral valve

Blood_Cultures.Results: Growth of Streptococcus gallolyticus from 3 different sites

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the risk factors and potential fetal anomalies in a pregnant woman with elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein levels.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has not been taking prenatal vitamins and admits to regular alcohol consumption. This is her first pregnancy.

Secondary_Symptoms: Normal levels of beta-human chorionic gonadotropin, estriol, and inhibin A

Pelvic_.Findings: Uterus consistent in size with 15 weeks' gestation

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the pathological findings associated with the cognitive decline and severe pneumonia in an elderly male patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient experienced worsening memory, behavior changes, and disorientation over several years, ultimately leading to hospitalization for severe pneumonia.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of anemia and weakness in a 56-year-old woman with a routine health maintenance .

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents for a routine health maintenance . She reports feeling weak and experiencing dyspnea during daily exercises. She has no significant past medical history, has not had menstrual bleeding for over 6 years, has a smoking history of half a pack of cigarettes for more than 20 years, and drinks alcohol occasionally. She takes ibuprofen for occasional headaches.

Physical_.Findings: Conjunctival pallor

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of severe right hip pain and assess for a potential malignancy based on imaging and clinical findings.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 2-month history of severe right hip pain, worsening at night. He also has chronic headaches and back pain for which he takes vitamin D, calcium supplements, and ibuprofen.

X-ray.Findings: Radiolucent lesion in the ilium with a moth-eaten appearance, wide transition zone, and an aggressive periosteal reaction

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of confusion and neurological symptoms in a patient with a history of HIV.

Patient_Actor.Demographics: 44-year-old male with a history of HIV infection
Patient_Actor.History: Presented to the emergency department after worsening confusion and disorientation noted by residents and staff at a homeless shelter. Reports headache and muscle aches but is unable to provide detailed history.

Secondary_Symptoms: Significant resistance and pain with knee extension while hips are flexed

Neurological_.Findings: Significant resistance and pain with knee extension while hips are flexed

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the patient's blood pressure and headache symptoms to determine the underlying condition related to hypertension during pregnancy.

Patient_Actor.History: Initial prenatal visit at 13 weeks' gestation. The patient has had episodic headaches over the past month and has no history of serious illness. Immunizations are up-to-date.

Pelvic_.Findings: Uterus consistent in size with a 13-week gestation; remainder of  shows no abnormalities.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage potential tuberculosis in a patient with a positive tuberculin skin test and respiratory symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents for a routine check-up and reports feeling less energetic than usual. He has a significant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes enalapril and atorvastatin. He has a 30-year history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily.

Secondary_Symptoms: Coarse breath sounds in lung bases

Lung_.Findings: Coarse breath sounds auscultated in lung bases bilaterally

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a pediatric patient presenting with constipation and anal fissure.

Patient_Actor.History: The boy has been noncompliant with toilet training and passes stools every 4 days, described as hard pellets. He was born weighing 7 lbs and 10 oz, remained in the hospital for one day post-delivery, and was exclusively breastfed for the first six months.

Secondary_Symptoms: Shallow tear in the posterior verge of the anus

Physical_Exam.Findings: Shallow tear in the posterior verge of the anus

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the effectiveness of antiretroviral therapy in a patient with HIV and determine the mechanism of action of the new drug regimen.

Patient_Actor.History: Ten months ago, the patient was diagnosed with HIV infection and started on appropriate antiretroviral therapy. He returns for a follow-up  due to increased viral load despite ongoing treatment.

Physical_.Findings: No abnormalities

Correct_Diagnosis: Viral fusion and entry into host cells

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of pruritus and jaundice in a patient with a history of ulcerative colitis.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with pruritus and jaundice. His past medical history includes ulcerative colitis diagnosed 2 years ago, which is well managed medically. He is vaccinated against hepatitis A and B and denies any recent travel abroad.

Physical_.Findings: Prominent hepatosplenomegaly noted on .

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the infectious etiology of respiratory distress and sore throat in a pediatric patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a sore throat and trouble breathing that started last night and has rapidly worsened. He is typically healthy, has received all childhood immunizations, and currently takes a daily multivitamin.

General_.Findings: Ill-appearing child who is drooling and leaning forward to breathe, non-compliant with oral .

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of progressive leg swelling and neurological symptoms in a patient with a history of HIV.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has experienced progressive swelling of his legs over the past 2 months, accompanied by an unintentional weight gain of 5 kg (11 lb). He reports frequent numbness in the tips of his fingers and cramping in his back and leg muscles. He has a history of HIV infection treated with combined antiretroviral therapy and immigrated to the US from Nigeria 3 years ago.

Secondary_Symptoms: Cramping in back and leg muscles

Physical_.Findings: 3+ periorbital and lower extremity edema bilaterally. Decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch around the mouth and along the fingers.

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify and manage anaphylaxis in a patient presenting with respiratory distress and rash following seafood consumption.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the emergency department after a sudden onset of shortness of breath, dry cough, nausea, and an itchy rash, which started 15 minutes after dinner at a seafood restaurant. The patient has a 2-year history of hypertension treated with enalapril and uses an albuterol inhaler for exercise-induced asthma. She is a smoker (one pack daily for 20 years) and consumes wine every other day. No history of illicit drug use.

Secondary_Symptoms: Erythematous patches and wheals on trunk, back, arms, and thighs

Skin_.Findings: Erythematous patches and wheals over trunk, back, upper arms, and thighs; slightly swollen lips

Respiratory_.Findings: Expiratory wheezing heard throughout both lung fields

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the most likely route of clearance for aerosolized particulate matter in a healthy subject.

Patient_Actor.History: Subject received an aerosol containing 6.7- μm sized particles via a nonrebreather mask for a study on new drug delivery systems.

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and manage a patient with altered mental status and potential decompression sickness following a diving incident.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient experienced seizure-like activity and loss of consciousness after a recreational dive. He has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and is on low-dose metoprolol, baby aspirin, and a multivitamin.

Correct_Diagnosis: Secure the patient's airway and administer 100% oxygen and rapid transport for recompression in a hyperbaric chamber.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of persistent left lower quadrant abdominal pain in a sexually active female with a positive pregnancy test.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of asthma and presents with persistent gnawing left lower quadrant abdominal pain. She has not traveled recently, tried new foods or medications, or been exposed to sick contacts. She is sexually active and has had multiple partners in the last year.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Persistent left lower quadrant abdominal pain
Secondary_Symptoms: Left lower quadrant tenderness to palpation

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the patient demographic most likely to exhibit decreased REM sleep, less total time sleeping, and more frequent nocturnal awakenings.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient has undergone sleep studies showing decreased REM sleep, less total time sleeping, and more frequent nocturnal awakenings.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and treat a patient presenting with vaginal discharge and irritation.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has been experiencing odorous yellow vaginal discharge and vaginal irritation for the past 3 days. She has no significant past medical history and is not diabetic. She has been sexually active with a single partner for the last 3 years.

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the child's failure to thrive and recurrent pulmonary infections to confirm the suspected diagnosis.

Patient_Actor.Demographics: 1-year-old child, born outside of the United States
Patient_Actor.History: The child is brought to a pediatrician for the first time due to concerns about not gaining weight. The child has a history of frequent pulmonary infections since birth.

Physical_Exam.Findings: Nasal polyps noted on

Genetic_Testing.Expected_Findings: Absence of phenylalanine from the protein involved in this child's condition

Correct_Diagnosis: Phenylketonuria (PKU) related to absence of phenylalanine

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the patient's generalized pain and symptoms related to chronic kidney disease and hemodialysis.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with generalized pain, particularly in the back, knees, elbows, and shoulders bilaterally. He has stage 4 chronic kidney disease and is on weekly hemodialysis, awaiting a renal transplant.

Secondary_Symptoms: Pain in back, knees, elbows, and shoulders bilaterally
Erythematous markings over forearms and trunk

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the underlying cause of abnormal behavior, memory issues, and involuntary movements in a patient with a recent change in mental status.

Patient_Actor.History: Presented with abnormal behavior and involuntary movements for the last 3 weeks. No significant past medical history except for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include metformin and a multivitamin. No history of fever, headache, head trauma, drug abuse, or change in medications.

Neurological_.Findings: Occasional episodic jerking of limbs, intact cranial nerves, normal extraocular movements, no neck stiffness.

EEG.Findings: Periodic spike and slow waves at an interval of 1 second

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the pathogenic agent responsible for the patient's weakness and neurological symptoms following a recent gastrointestinal illness.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the emergency room after complaints of weakness during a soccer match. Parents noted clumsiness during practice the day before and abdominal pain with bloody diarrhea the previous week, which resolved without medical attention.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Weakness and inability to get back up after falling
Secondary_Symptoms: Reduced reflexes (1+ bilaterally for Achilles and patellar reflexes)
Muscle strength deficits in foot dorsiflexion (3/5) and plantar flexion (3/5), knee extension (4-/5) and knee flexion (4-/5)

Neurological_.Findings: Intact vibration and proprioception, reduced reflexes, and muscle strength deficits in specific lower extremity movements.

Objective_for_Doctor: Provide appropriate recommendations for cervical cancer screening for a sexually active adolescent.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents for an annual wellness checkup with no known past medical history and non-significant social and family histories. She is up to date on her childhood and adolescent vaccinations.

Correct_Diagnosis: Begin 3-year interval cervical cancer screening via Pap smear at age 21

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the management plan for a woman in active labor at term with uncomplicated pregnancy.

Patient_Actor.History: Admitted to the hospital at 40 weeks of gestation in active labor. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated, with regular prenatal check-ups and no history of serious illness. First child delivered via normal vaginal delivery.

Secondary_Symptoms: Softening of the cervix without visible fetal parts or prolapsed umbilical cord

Cervical_.Findings: 80% effacement, 5 cm dilation, softening without visible fetal parts or prolapsed umbilical cord

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the psychological factors contributing to the reappearance of bedwetting in a child after a significant family change.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient started bedwetting days after the birth of his newborn sister. The father punished him for bedwetting, which exacerbated the issue.

Secondary_Symptoms: Emotional distress related to the new sibling

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the safe blood type(s) for transfusion in a patient with AB+ blood type after significant blood loss.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought in by ambulance after being struck by a truck while crossing the street, resulting in significant blood loss.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Loss of large volume of blood

Correct_Diagnosis: A+, A-, B+, B-, AB+, AB-, O+, O-

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and manage a patient presenting with bloody vomiting and signs of potential esophageal variceal hemorrhage.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a long history of alcoholism with recent progression to liver cirrhosis and known esophageal varices. She presents with bloody vomiting for the last hour, sudden onset chest and epigastric pain, and bruising more easily over the last 3 months.

Abdominal_.Findings: Pain on palpation of epigastrium and chest without crepitus

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine appropriate follow-up care for a pregnant patient with well-controlled type II pregestational diabetes mellitus.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a medical history of type II pregestational diabetes mellitus, which has been well-controlled with diet and insulin throughout her pregnancy.

Correct_Diagnosis: Twice weekly nonstress test now until delivery

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the underlying cause of chest pain and evaluate for potential esophageal dysfunction.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the cardiologist with spontaneous chest pain radiating to his back, ears, and neck. He denies dyspnea on exertion.

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the underlying cause of persistent back pain, fatigue, and renal impairment in a middle-aged male patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with complaints of persistent back pain and fatigue over the past 12 months.

Secondary_Symptoms: Renal impairment (serum creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL)
Proteinuria (4.5 g of protein excreted in urine over 24 hours)

Renal_Biopsy.Findings: Eosinophilic, acellular material in the glomerular tuft and capillary walls showing apple green-colored birefringence in polarized light upon Congo red staining.

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess management strategies for a patient with diagnosed hypertension and evaluate lifestyle factors.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient diagnosed with hypertension 3 months ago. He has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 4 years ago. Occasionally drinks alcohol on weekends. Engages in regular walking for exercise and has made dietary changes since diagnosis.

Physical_.Findings: No abnormalities noted

Objective_for_Doctor: Educate the mother about the common causes of death in children aged 5-9 and reassure her about the safety of school lunches.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the clinic by her anxious mother on her 5th birthday, prompted by concerns from an email about pesticide-coated fruit in school lunches.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Anxiety from the mother regarding perceived health risks

Correct_Diagnosis: Unintentional injury, malignant neoplasms, congenital anomalies

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of confusion and seizure in a young adult with fever and headache.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department in a state of confusion after experiencing a seizure approximately 45 minutes prior. He has been complaining of fever and headache for the past 3 days. No reported history of nausea, vomiting, head trauma, sore throat, skin rash, or abdominal pain.

Secondary_Symptoms: Sensitivity to light and loud noises

Neurological_.Findings: Patient is awake but confused and disoriented; fundus  is benign.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of worsening peripheral neuropathy and assess potential complications of diabetes mellitus.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and presents with worsening tingling of her feet at night for the last 6 months. She underwent retinal laser photocoagulation in both eyes two years ago and has not adhered to her insulin regimen.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Worsening tingling of the feet at night
Secondary_Symptoms: Decreased sense of vibration and proprioception in toes and ankles

Neurological_.Findings: Decreased sense of vibration and proprioception in toes and ankles bilaterally

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of bilateral knee pain in a patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and recommend appropriate pharmacotherapy.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has experienced bilateral knee pain for the past year, which worsens with movement and is relieved by rest. She has a family history of joint conditions, as her mother takes leflunomide. Current medications include metformin and a multivitamin.

Knee_.Findings: Pain in complete flexion and extension, crepitus, joint stiffness, and restricted range of motion in both knees.

Imaging.X-ray Findings: Irregular joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and several subchondral cysts.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate surgical management for a skin defect on the ankle after a pedestrian accident.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient had a pedestrian accident 3 days ago resulting in a skin defect on the dorsal side of his left ankle. The lesion was cleaned, debrided, and observed over the past 3 days. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications.

Local_.Findings: No signs of local infection observed on the ankle lesion

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the cause of hair loss and determine the appropriate treatment based on the patient's response.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents seeking treatment for baldness, having noticed a bald patch in the center of his head that has increased in size over the past year. No evidence of an infectious cause was found upon .

Hair_.Findings: Bald patch with no signs of infection

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of abdominal pain, jaundice, and hematuria in a 45-year-old male with a history of low blood counts and recent alcohol use.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with nausea and severe abdominal pain. He recently finalized a divorce and consumed multiple shots of tequila and vodka. He noticed red urine this morning. Past medical history includes low blood counts diagnosed 6 months ago, which were not followed up due to stress from the divorce. He also reports erectile dysfunction and chronic fatigue.

Physical_.Findings: Scleral icterus, pale mucous membranes, systolic flow murmur loudest along the left sternal border, moderate right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness.

Objective_for_Doctor: Manage a patient with COPD exacerbation and respiratory failure following an upper respiratory tract infection.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of COPD and was admitted with difficulty breathing and increased sputum production after developing an upper respiratory tract infection approximately one week ago.

Chest_Radiograph.Findings: Consolidation in the lower lobe of the right lung

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the causes and management of neonatal jaundice with accompanying symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the physician due to yellowish discoloration of eyes and body, vomiting, and poor feeding for 3 days. The newborn has had diarrhea for the past 2 days. Born at 38 weeks' gestation, antenatal period was uncomplicated.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae
Secondary_Symptoms: Decreased muscle tone in all extremities

Vital_Signs.N/A: Vital signs are within normal limits

General_.Findings: Bilateral cataracts, soft and nontender abdomen, liver palpated 4-cm below the right costal margin, no splenomegaly.

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the abnormal cell types present in the esophagus of a patient with chronic heartburn and intestinal metaplasia.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of chronic heartburn, and an esophageal biopsy was performed.

Biopsy_Results.Findings: Intestinal metaplasia with the presence of abnormal cell types.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the prominent histologic finding in the area of a prior stroke in a patient with a history of ischemic stroke.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient had a history of stroke one year ago and was found unconscious at home. She expired prior to arrival at the emergency department.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the cause of sudden onset fever and joint pain in a young male patient with recent gastrointestinal illness.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with sudden onset of fever for the past few hours, pain and swelling in the right knee and left ankle. He recently recovered from gastroenteritis with significant abdominal pain and bloody stool 4 weeks ago, believed to be related to undercooked chicken.

Secondary_Symptoms: Pain and swelling in right knee
Pain and swelling in left ankle

Joint_.Findings: Tenderness to palpation of right knee and left ankle

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a patient presenting with bilateral breast pain and fullness post-delivery.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presented for breast pain and reported experiencing bilateral breast fullness and tenderness. She gave birth to an infant girl 2 weeks ago at 40 weeks gestation and has been feeding her baby formula only.

Breast_.Findings: Bilateral breast fullness with tenderness upon palpation; breasts warmer than forehead

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of the infant's left arm immobility following delivery and identify the likely nerve roots involved.

Patient_Actor.History: At 40 weeks' gestation, the patient presented with contractions spaced 2 minutes apart. She has a significant medical history of diabetes controlled with insulin during this pregnancy. The pregnancy was otherwise unremarkable.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Inability to move left arm away from body
Secondary_Symptoms: Left arm pronated and medially rotated
Good oxygen saturation on room air

Infant_.Findings: Weight 4.5 kg (9 lb), left arm immobility

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of repeated bruising, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy in a middle-aged woman.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with repeated bruising over the past week, with some bruises developing spontaneously and others following minor trauma. She reports significant fatigue and weakness for the past 4 months and reduced appetite for a few months. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history shows both parents are alive and healthy. Social history includes social alcohol consumption and no smoking.

Secondary_Symptoms: Mild bilateral cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy

General_.Findings: Mild bilateral cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy, multiple petechiae and ecchymoses, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly.

Morphological_Characteristics.Findings: Myeloperoxidase positive and contains azurophilic crystal rods

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the ECG leads that would show ST elevations associated with an acute myocardial infarction in a patient presenting with chest pain.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of nausea and retrosternal chest pain. She has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and is currently taking atorvastatin, metformin, and lisinopril.

Cardiac_Imaging.Findings: Photograph of coronary angiography performed prior to percutaneous coronary intervention

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of confusion and malaise in an elderly woman with a history of multiple comorbidities.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a past medical history of poorly controlled diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, obesity, and recurrent urinary tract infections. She is brought to the emergency room due to confusion, generalized malaise, weakness, nausea, and mild lower abdominal pain.

Cardiac_.Findings: No murmurs heard

Abdominal_.Findings: Soft and non-distended abdomen with involuntary guarding in the suprapubic region

Peripheral_.Findings: Bounding femoral pulses and trace bilateral pedal edema

ECG.Findings: Normal amplitude sinus tachycardia without evidence of ST-segment changes or T-wave inversions

Correct_Diagnosis: Decreased PCWP; slightly increased SaO2; increased CO; decreased SVR

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and identify the cause of pelvic pain and vaginal discharge in a young woman.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with pelvic pain and vaginal discharge that began 2 days ago. She has no history of serious medical illness and is not taking any medications.

Secondary_Symptoms: Pain with movement of the cervix

Pelvic_.Findings: Pain with movement of the cervix and mucopurulent cervical discharge

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of skin changes and systemic symptoms in a patient with a recent leg stab wound and diabetes.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department with skin changes on his leg that developed over the past 24 hours. He accidentally stabbed himself in the leg 4 days ago with a knife. He has a 10-year history of diabetes mellitus and is taking metformin.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate behavioral concerns in a child and assess for possible diagnosis of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD).

Patient_Actor.History: Brought by parents due to concerns about behavior at school over the past year, including leaving his seat, running around the classroom, and difficulty waiting for his turn. Better behavior at home but frequently acts out inappropriately. No serious illnesses and up to date on all vaccines.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a patient presenting with episodic left periorbital pain suggestive of cluster headaches.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has experienced episodic left periorbital pain radiating to the left frontotemporal area for the past 2 weeks. Each episode lasts 1-2 hours and is accompanied by lacrimation and a runny nose on the left side. He has a history of myocardial infarction 1 year ago, with ongoing angina on exertion. He has a 10 pack-year smoking history.

Secondary_Symptoms: Runny nose on the left side

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying metabolic changes in a newborn with jaundice and laboratory findings suggestive of a hemolytic process.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought by mother due to noted skin yellowing (jaundice).

Secondary_Symptoms: Blood smear findings indicative of hemolysis

Correct_Diagnosis: Right shift of the oxyhemoglobin curve

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and manage a previously healthy child presenting with fever and diarrhea, potentially indicating dehydration.

Patient_Actor.History: The child has a 36-hour history of fever and profuse, watery diarrhea, with several other children at his daycare exhibiting similar symptoms. He has not received routine childhood vaccines due to parental concerns about side effects.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate management for a patient with progressive difficulty in walking and cognitive decline likely due to normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 12-month history of progressive difficulty in walking and maintaining balance, with reports of slow walking, difficulty turning, and feet seeming 'glued to the ground'. She also experiences problems recalling names and recent events. Past medical history includes essential hypertension treated with losartan and urinary incontinence managed with oxybutynin.

Secondary_Symptoms: Cognitive decline (difficulty recalling names and recent events)
Slow gait with short steps and poor foot clearance

Neurologic_.Findings: Slow gait with short steps and poor foot clearance

Imaging.Head_CT: Findings consistent with normal pressure hydrocephalus

Lumbar_Puncture.Result: Transient improvement in gait for 3 days

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a patient with dysphagia, oral thrush, and positive HIV test.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-week history of progressive pain while swallowing and a sensation of food getting stuck in her throat. She has a history of high-grade cervical dysplasia treated with conization 12 years ago and was diagnosed with Graves' disease 4 months ago. Current medications include methimazole and a vitamin supplement.

Secondary_Symptoms: Feeling that food gets stuck in the throat
White plaques in the oral cavity that can be scraped off easily

Oral_.Findings: Several white plaques that can be scraped off easily

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate screening recommendations for a healthy 47-year-old woman with a past medical history of hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis.

Patient_Actor.History: Presenting for a routine pap smear. Past medical history includes hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications are levothyroxine, methotrexate, and adalimumab.

Physical_.Findings: Grossly normal

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the necessity for continued omeprazole therapy in a patient with Barrett's esophagus during an annual checkup.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with biopsy confirming Barrett's esophagus. He is currently on therapy with omeprazole. Review of systems is unremarkable, and he is otherwise doing well.

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of acute gout attack and initiate appropriate long-term management.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with intense, sharp pain in his toe for the past hour. He has a history of similar symptoms and this is his 2nd visit to the emergency department this year with the same complaint.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Intense, sharp pain in the right 1st toe

Physical__Findings.Findings: Significant erythema, swelling, warmth, and moderate pain on palpation of the right 1st toe

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of splenomegaly, night sweats, and weight loss in a 67-year-old man.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was referred for a follow-up  after splenomegaly was detected 1 month ago. He has experienced night sweats for several months and has lost 5 kg (11 lb) unintentionally. He has no history of severe illness and takes no medications.

Physical__Findings.Findings: Splenomegaly present

Ultrasound.Findings: Spleen size 15 cm and mild hepatomegaly

Peripheral_Blood_Smear.Findings: Teardrop-shaped and nucleated red blood cells (RBCs) and immature myeloid cells

Bone_Marrow.Findings: Hyperplasia of all 3 lineages; difficult to aspirate

Cytogenetic_Analysis.Result: Negative for translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of prolonged fever, cough, and weight loss in a pediatric patient with a recent immigration history.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the office with fever and cough lasting for the past month. The family moved from Africa to the United States about 8 months ago. The patient has lost weight since her last visit 6 months ago for immunizations and a well-child visit.

Secondary_Symptoms: Diminished breath sounds from the right hemithorax

Physical_.Findings: Breathing normally with no nasal discharge; presence of moderate non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy bilaterally; diminished breath sounds from the right hemithorax

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the most appropriate vaccination recommendation for a 62-year-old woman during a routine check-up.

Patient_Actor.History: Chronic back pain, underwent appendectomy at age 27, recently returned from a cruise to Mexico to celebrate 40th wedding anniversary. Last mammogram was 6 months ago (no abnormalities), last Pap smear was 2 years ago (unremarkable), and normal colonoscopy 5 years ago. Family history includes mother who died of breast cancer and father with arterial hypertension. Immunization records indicate never received pneumococcal or shingles vaccine, last tetanus booster was 6 years ago, and last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago.

Secondary_Symptoms: Regular physical activity (water aerobics and physical therapy)
Occasional alcohol consumption (1-2 drinks per weekend)

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of subepidermal blisters on the flexor surfaces in an adult male patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with blisters on the flexor surfaces of his arms and legs that appeared 2 days ago. He has a history of similar blisters in the past but has not sought medical attention until now. No significant past medical history.

Secondary_Symptoms: Lesions have not improved in 2 days

Skin_.Findings: Tense bullae present on the flexor surfaces of the arms and legs

Biopsy_Results.Findings: Subepidermal blister with a polymorphous but predominantly eosinophilic infiltrate

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the underlying cause of fever, joint pain, and systemic symptoms in a pediatric patient with a recent history of sore throat.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with fever, malaise, and severe right knee joint pain and swelling for 3 days. He experienced abdominal pain and epistaxis during this time. Five days prior, he had swelling and pain in his left ankle joint which has resolved. He had a sore throat 3 weeks ago while camping and received symptomatic treatment. Immunizations are up-to-date.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Severe right knee joint pain and swelling

Joint_.Findings: Swollen, tender right knee; limited range of motion

Skin_.Findings: Painless 3- to 4-mm nodules over the elbow

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the cause of intermittent double vision and impaired eye movement following a recent bicycling accident.

Patient_Actor.History: One week after being involved in a bicycling accident, the patient reports intermittent double vision, which worsens when typing or buttoning shirts.

Secondary_Symptoms: Left eye deviation laterally and upwards

Neurological_.Findings: Left eye deviated laterally and upwards with prominent deviation during left eye adduction

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying mechanism of facial swelling and difficulties speaking and swallowing in a patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presented after waking up with facial swelling and difficulty speaking and swallowing. No known allergies or recent insect bites. She has a 4-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with medication.

Secondary_Symptoms: Notable swelling of the lips and tongue

Physical_Exam.Findings: Notable swelling of the lips and tongue; no other abnormalities

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the underlying cause of headaches and muscle weakness in an elderly patient with systemic symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with increasing muscle pain and stiffness, along with weakness in her shoulders and legs, and generalized fatigue over the past 4 months. She has experienced difficulty getting out of bed, weight loss of 4 kg (9 lb), and poor sleep. Additionally, she reports multiple episodes of left-sided headaches and jaw pain while chewing over the past 2 months. Notably, she had a fall and hit her head 3 months ago.

Secondary_Symptoms: Limited range of motion in shoulders and hips

Neurological_.Findings: Normal muscle strength in bilateral upper and lower extremities, deep tendon reflexes 2+ bilaterally

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of acute confusion and agitation in a patient with a history of diabetes and medication use.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the emergency department with acute onset confusion, disorientation, and agitation. The patient's wife reports he has diabetic gastroparesis and takes domperidone, insulin glargine, and insulin lispro for type 1 diabetes, and telmisartan for hypertension. He mistakenly took 4 tablets of scopolamine instead of his morning dose of domperidone.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of multiple swellings on the scalp of a 6-month-old boy and assess associated urinary frequency.

Patient_Actor.History: The child has had multiple swellings on his scalp for 2 months, first noticed as 3 softened and swollen areas that have grown in size. He is also urinating more frequently than usual. Born by cesarean section at 39 weeks gestation with appropriate prenatal care.

Secondary_Symptoms: Tenderness on palpation of scalp swellings

Physical_.Findings: 3 areas of soft tissue swelling on the skull, tender to palpation, and moderate asymmetric exophthalmos.

CT_Scan.Findings: Multifocal lytic calvarial lesions

Biopsy.Expected_Findings: Rod-shaped granules with a latticed matrix

Correct_Diagnosis: Rod-shaped granules with a latticed matrix

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of back pain and lower extremity numbness following an emergency cesarean delivery.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient experienced back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery due to placental abruption, resulting in a blood loss of approximately 2000 ml. She received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids during the procedure. No history of serious illness and no current medications.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Back pain and numbness in lower extremities
Secondary_Symptoms: Decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below waist
Absence of deep tendon reflexes in lower extremities
2+ deep tendon reflexes in upper extremities
Vibration sense intact in great toes

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the cause of hirsutism and delayed menstruation in a 14-year-old girl.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with concerns of excessive hair growth on the upper lip and cheeks, sparse hairs on the chest, and absence of menstruation. She was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery, is up to date on vaccines, and is meeting developmental milestones.

Secondary_Symptoms: Pustular acne on face and shoulders
Thin dark hair on upper lip and cheeks

Physical_.Findings: Thin dark hair on upper lip and cheeks, pustular acne on face and shoulders, initial breast development

Objective_for_Doctor: Investigate the cardioprotective effects of omega-3 fatty acids on post-myocardial infarction patients.

Patient_Actor.History: Research focuses on the relationship between inflammatory mediators and omega-3 fatty acids, specifically docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA). The study examines the role of IL-1β in fibrosis and arrhythmias after MI.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Arrhythmogenic state due to loss of function in gap junction connexin 43 (Cx43)

Laboratory_Analysis.Western_Blot_Analysis: Results indicate the cardioprotective effect of DHA against IL-1β effects in post-MI cells.

Correct_Diagnosis: Fatty acids with double bonds in the 3rd position adjacent to the terminal carbon are cardioprotective against the effects of IL-1β in post-MI cells.

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the risks associated with drug management in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis and a history of alcoholic hepatitis.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of alcoholic hepatitis and has been diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis, for which she has started NSAIDs. She returns for follow-up due to ongoing joint effusions and increasing morning stiffness.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of easy bruising and bleeding in a patient with a history of cholecystectomy and gastrointestinal symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with easy bruising and bleeding over the last 6 months. She has also experienced fatty, foul-smelling stools. She had a cholecystectomy a year ago due to symptomatic gallstones.

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the health risks of a 54-year-old male patient and recommend preventative measures to reduce all-cause mortality.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient comes for an annual health maintenance . He has a long history of smoking (one pack daily for 22 years) and consumes three 12-oz bottles of beer every night. He works as an accountant and does not have time for regular exercise.

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the cause of fever, malaise, and bilateral facial pain and swelling in a 14-year-old boy with a recent travel history.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the physician with fever, malaise, and bilateral facial pain and swelling that began 2 days ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He was born in India, and his mother received no prenatal care. She is unsure of his childhood vaccination history. He returned from a trip to India 3 weeks ago.

Secondary_Symptoms: Erythema and tenderness of parotid glands

_Findings.Parotid_Glands: Erythema, edema, and tenderness of the right and left parotid glands

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of confusion, memory deficits, and left leg weakness in an elderly female patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has experienced confusion and memory deficits for the last month, along with mild weakness in her left leg. She has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. The patient is a long-term smoker, consuming two packs of cigarettes daily for 45 years, and drinks a glass of wine every day.

Secondary_Symptoms: Inability to lift eyebrows or smile
Decreased muscle strength in left lower extremity

Imaging.MRI Findings: Several hyperintense round lesions in the frontal and temporal lobe at the border of the gray and white matter

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the RNA equivalent of a technique used to identify specific DNA fragments in a genome.

Patient_Actor.History: N/A

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of persistent abdominal pain, early satiety, hematemesis, and associated symptoms in a postmenopausal woman.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with 4 months of persistent abdominal pain and early satiety that has worsened recently. She experienced several episodes of hematemesis and has been sexually active with her husband. She reports pain with intercourse and spotting after intercourse. Additionally, she has been experiencing nausea and weight loss.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the patient for symptoms related to possible hypothyroidism secondary to phenytoin use.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a long-standing history of a seizure disorder diagnosed 10 years ago and recently switched medications to phenytoin 300 mg orally daily. She reports worsening symptoms of fatigue, weight gain, and hair loss over the past month.

General_.Findings: Slow to respond but cooperative, skin is coarse and dry, mild to moderate hair loss over the entire body, and remaining hair is brittle.

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of respiratory distress in a newborn following delivery.

Patient_Actor.Demographics: Newborn, 2.4 kg (5.3 lb), born at 38 weeks gestation
Patient_Actor.History: Developed respiratory distress 24 hours after delivery.

Secondary_Symptoms: Heart sounds in the right hemithorax
Absent lung sounds on the left side

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the underlying condition causing acute left-sided visual loss in an elderly patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presented to the emergency department with left-sided visual loss that started 1 hour ago. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Abrupt, complete loss of central vision in the left eye
Secondary_Symptoms: Initially seeing jagged edges of vision

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the likely pathogen responsible for bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain following a recent camping trip.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with 4 days of abdominal pain and increasingly frequent bloody diarrhea after a long camping trip where she cooked her own food and drank water from nearby streams.

Secondary_Symptoms: 6 episodes of moderate volume diarrhea per day

Abdominal_.Findings: Negative for acute tenderness, rebound tenderness, or abnormal bowel sounds

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the cause of altered mental status and autonomic instability in a young male.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is a seasonal farm worker with a past medical history of IV drug use, marijuana use, and alcohol use. He was found laying under a tree and was minimally responsive. Current medications include ibuprofen.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate therapeutic and diagnostic procedure for a patient with chronic idiopathic pericardial effusion and persistent chest pain.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a previous diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis and Sjogren syndrome, with a known chronic idiopathic pericardial effusion for about a year. She has undergone two diagnostic pericardiocenteses, which resulted in fluid return each time, and has used NSAIDs and colchicine without significant changes in effusion size. The etiological testing was negative.

Secondary_Symptoms: No evidence of distended neck veins
Sinus rhythm with low QRS voltages on ECG

ECG_Findings.Findings: Sinus rhythm with low QRS voltages

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of the patient's clumsiness and falls.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a history of feeling abnormally clumsy, tripping, and bumping into things. He admits to having unprotected sex with multiple partners recently but states he is otherwise healthy.

Physical_Exam.Findings: Broad-based and unstable gait

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the renal function and characteristics of the nephron segment associated with Bartter's syndrome.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is being evaluated for suspected Bartter's syndrome, a renal disorder characterized by defective Cl- reabsorption.

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the patient's decision-making capacity regarding the placement of a feeding tube following a stroke.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient developed dysphagia after a stroke secondary to a patent foramen ovale. He has a history of major depressive disorder with psychotic features, treated with fluoxetine. He is alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation, and denies any hallucinations or suicidal ideation.

Secondary_Symptoms: Weight loss of 10 pounds due to limited caloric intake
Understanding of risks of not placing a feeding tube (aspiration, malnutrition, death)

Correct_Diagnosis: The patient has capacity and may deny placement of the feeding tube

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of the child's symptoms and identify the impaired enzyme leading to sideroblastic anemia.

Patient_Actor.History: The family recently moved from Nebraska to Texas. The child had been developing normally until 3 months after the move, when symptoms of lethargy, fatigue, pallor, and constipation began.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying mechanism of drug resistance in an HIV-infected patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is infected with an HIV strain that is resistant to saquinavir and zidovudine.

Secondary_Symptoms: Potential for opportunistic infections (not specified in scenario)
Viral load may be increased due to resistance (not specified in scenario)

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate alternative antipsychotic medication for a patient experiencing restlessness due to trifluoperazine.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of schizophrenia and was started on trifluoperazine three weeks ago. He reports worsening restlessness, feeling compelled to pace, and being unable to sit or stand still. Following a switch in medication, he reports improvement but has developed increased drowsiness, blurred vision, and dry mouth.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the patient's symptoms to assess for potential thyroid dysfunction.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with complaints of fatigue, decreased energy over the last three months, and a weight gain of 7 pounds. Review of systems is negative for depression but includes positive findings for constipation, myalgias, and cold intolerance.

Neurological_.Findings: Delayed deep tendon reflex relaxation

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of an itchy rash and determine if there are underlying health issues.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has no significant past medical, surgical, social, or family history. He presents to the clinic with an itchy rash and has a negative review of systems.

Skin_.Findings: Crusting vesicular clusters on upper back with a base of erythema and surrounding edema

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of a progressively worsening rash in a 4-month-old boy.

Patient_Actor.History: The boy has had a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks for the last week. He cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual.

Secondary_Symptoms: Erythematous papules and plaques in bilateral inguinal creases
Erythematous lesions on the scrotum and in the gluteal cleft

Skin_.Findings: Erythematous papules and plaques with small areas of maceration

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain in a 13-year-old girl.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with sporadic vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain over the past 4 months. Currently, she has soaked through 1 pad today. She denies being sexually active or using any illicit substances.

Physical_Exam.Findings: Healthy young girl with non-focal abdominal and pelvic exam

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the psychological defense mechanisms exhibited by the patient in the context of his abusive behavior.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is physically and verbally abusive towards his wife and two children. He has a history of childhood abuse, having been similarly abused by his father alongside his mother.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Physical and verbal abuse towards family

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of abnormal olfactory experiences and nasal symptoms in a 50-year-old male.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports smelling burnt rubber intermittently over the past 6 months, with no one else able to smell it. He has had occasional nosebleeds during this time. He works as a high school teacher and has an unremarkable family history. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and denies the use of any medications.

Nasal_.Findings: Unilateral nasal obstruction with dried blood in the nasal passage

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of acute back pain in a young male with a history of IV drug abuse and recent heavy lifting.
