Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Foul-smelling diarrhea with bulky and floating stools
Secondary_Symptoms: Areas of hypoesthesia in the hands and feet

Skin_.Findings: Grouped, papulovesicular, pruritic skin lesions

Neurological_.Findings: Areas of hypoesthesia in the hands and feet

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the predisposing factors for angiosarcoma in a patient with a history of breast cancer.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of breast cancer, coronary artery disease, gastroesophageal reflux, and diabetes mellitus. Recently, she was diagnosed with angiosarcoma.

Secondary_Symptoms: History of mastectomy with lymph node dissection

Correct_Diagnosis: History of mastectomy with lymph node dissection

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of skin changes and blistering in a patient with chronic hepatitis C.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 10-day history of darkening of the skin and painless blisters. He began working as a landscaper 2 weeks ago and consumes 2 beers every night, occasionally drinking more on weekends.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Darkening of the skin and painless blisters
Secondary_Symptoms: Bullae and oozing erosions on arms, dorsal hands, and face
Patches of hyperpigmented skin on arms and face

Skin_.Findings: Bullae and oozing erosions in different stages of healing on arms, dorsal hands, and face; atrophic white scars; patches of hyperpigmented skin

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the mental health status of a young man presenting with symptoms of mood disorder and determine the appropriate treatment.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department by his father for not sleeping for 2 nights consecutively. He has exhibited unusual mood changes, including disrobing in front of guests and engaging in lengthy conversations with strangers. One month ago, he took out a large loan for a business idea he has yet to start and borrowed his father's credit card for a spontaneous trip to Switzerland, spending over 30,000 dollars. His father also reports episodes where he isolates himself in his room for extended periods.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Mood instability with episodes of hyperactivity and severe fatigue
Secondary_Symptoms: Episodes of sleeping for approximately 15 hours

Mental_Status.Findings: Talkative, distractible, flight of ideas, pressured speech, difficult to interrupt, and intrusive questioning

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and manage a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of a psychotic disorder.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient has been experiencing auditory hallucinations and believes she is receiving threatening messages through newspaper articles for the past year. She feels that someone is trying to kill her and has isolated herself from family and friends due to their disbelief in her experiences. She denies any use of illicit drugs.

Secondary_Symptoms: Increased distress due to beliefs of being targeted

Mental_Status_.Findings: Normal affect; no physical abnormalities noted.

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and manage acute respiratory distress in a patient with a history of asthma.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the emergency department for shortness of breath that began suddenly while walking up a flight of stairs. She has a past medical history of asthma, constipation, irritable bowel syndrome, and anxiety. Current medications include albuterol, fluticasone, loratadine, and sodium docusate.

Secondary_Symptoms: Inability to resolve symptoms with albuterol
Oxygen saturation of 85% on room air
Poor air movement and absence of wheezing

Respiratory_.Findings: Poor air movement and absence of wheezing

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate management for a patient presenting with episodic abdominal pain and a liver mass consistent with a potential parasitic infection.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with episodic abdominal pain and fullness lasting for 1 month. The pain radiates from the epigastrium to the right upper quadrant and lasts up to 2 hours without aggravation by eating. She reports severe nausea and has had 6 episodes of vomiting in the last 3 days. She works as an assistant at an animal shelter.

Secondary_Symptoms: Vomiting (6 episodes over the last 3 days)
Palpable 4-cm smooth mass below the right costal margin (nontender, moves with respiration)

Abdominal_.Findings: Palpable 4-cm smooth mass below the right costal margin, nontender, moves with respiration

Ultrasound.Findings: Unilocular cyst 4 cm in diameter with daughter cysts within the liver

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of fever, limping, and localized tenderness in a 3-year-old boy.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 3-day history of fever and chills, with recent limping for 2 days and no reported trauma.

Secondary_Symptoms: Dull tenderness over left lower extremity
Limited range of motion of the leg due to pain
Avoidance of weight bearing on left leg

Musculoskeletal_.Findings: Dull tenderness over left lower extremity with limited range of motion

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying genetic disease causing recurrent infections in a 1-year-old boy.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with fever and persistent cough for the past 5 days. He has a history of recurrent skin infections, ear infections, and pneumonia since birth, caused by organisms including Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas, and Candida.

Secondary_Symptoms: Prominent facial scars in periorbital and nasal regions from healed abscesses

Physical_Exam.Findings: Prominent facial scars in the periorbital and nasal regions

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate nutritional management for a patient in the intensive care unit post-surgery for an epidural hemorrhage.

Patient_Actor.History: Admitted to the hospital after a fall from a two-story building, was somnolent and not oriented upon arrival. Underwent emergency craniotomy and hematoma evacuation.

Secondary_Symptoms: Postoperative care in intensive care unit

CT_Scan.Findings: Epidural hemorrhage (45 cm3) with midline shift (7 mm)

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cellular structures that protect the central nervous system from bacterial penetration in the context of a patient with endocarditis and altered mental status.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presented with altered mental status that began approximately two weeks prior, accompanied by increasing fatigue, malaise, loss of appetite, and subjective fever.

Secondary_Symptoms: Holosystolic murmur in the tricuspid area
Linear non-blanching reddish lesions under the nails
Needle tracks on both antecubital fossae

Cardiovascular_.Findings: Holosystolic murmur in the tricuspid area

Dermatological_.Findings: Linear non-blanching reddish lesions under the nails and needle tracks on both antecubital fossae

Echocardiogram.Findings: Vegetation on the tricuspid valve

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the cellular structure involved in the synthesis of galactose-alpha-1,3-galactose in a patient with alpha-gal allergy.

Patient_Actor.History: Diagnosed with alpha-gal allergy (mammalian meat allergy) due to a reaction to galactose-alpha-1,3-galactose.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of amenorrhea and abnormal karyotype in a young female patient with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia and presents with amenorrhea for 12 months. Menarche occurred at age 11 with regular 28-day menstrual cycles until irregularities began one year ago.

Secondary_Symptoms: Irregular menses for the past year

Pelvic_.Findings: Normal female genitalia and normal-sized uterus

Blood_Tests.FSH: Markedly elevated levels consistent with premature ovarian failure

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of palpitations and hypertension in a young premedical student potentially related to stress or underlying medical conditions.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is a premedical student who traveled abroad for a global health service semester. She presents with palpitations that have increased in frequency, initially dismissed as a side effect of working too hard. She also reports headaches and episodes of sweating, with a family history of migraines.

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the underlying cause of the child's symptoms and confirm the diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 1-month history of loss of appetite, fatigability, unexplained irritability, and intermittent low-grade fever. The mother reports frequent bone pain, especially in the lower limbs.

General_Exam.Findings: Generalized pallor, splenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, tenderness to palpation of lower extremities without joint swelling, warmth or erythema.

Bone_Marrow_Biopsy.Findings: 30% of the bone marrow cells as a homogeneous population of lymphoblasts

Immunophenotyping.Diagnosis: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) of precursor-B subtype

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of anemia and bleeding in a young child with elevated leukocyte count.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought in due to a 2-week history of generalized fatigue, intermittent fever, and occasional nosebleeds. His mother reports that he appears pale.

Abdominal_.Findings: Spleen palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin

General_.Findings: Pale appearance, cervical lymphadenopathy, multiple petechiae

Bone_Marrow_Aspirate.Findings: Predominantly immature leukocytes staining positive for CD10, CD19, and terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT), negative for myeloperoxidase

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cognitive and behavioral changes indicative of a neurodegenerative disorder.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 3-year history of progressive memory loss and changes in personality. Initially, she forgot day-to-day items and directions, and recently has shown increased impatience, aggression, and occasional violent behavior. Her past medical history includes diabetes and hypertension, managed with metformin and lisinopril.

General_.Findings: Unremarkable

Correct_Diagnosis: Neurodegenerative disorder (likely frontotemporal dementia based on personality changes)

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose potential eating disorders based on the physical  and patient history.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is presenting for her annual check-up with a past medical history significant for sexual abuse in her teens. Currently, she has no complaints and reports her last menstrual period was 1 week ago.

Secondary_Symptoms: Calluses on the dorsum of the right hand

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess fetal well-being due to the patient's decreased perception of fetal movements and determine the next steps in management.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents for a prenatal checkup with concerns about decreased fetal movements, having felt the baby move only eight times over an hour period. Prenatal history includes morning sickness requiring pyridoxine, and a second-trimester ultrasound showed no abnormal placental attachment. She takes a daily multivitamin.

Secondary_Symptoms: Fundal height growth from 26 cm to 28 cm in two weeks

Physical_.Findings: Unremarkable

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the underlying cause of progressive memory loss and neurological symptoms in a 63-year-old woman.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient has experienced progressive memory loss for the past 5 months, with recent issues in getting dressed and navigating familiar places. She has episodes of jerky, repetitive, twitching movements that resolve spontaneously. Previously worked as a teacher but quit due to memory loss. Medical history includes hypertension. No family history of serious illness. Currently taking hydrochlorothiazide.

Neurological_.Findings: Oriented only to person and place, follows commands, speaks fluently, but has difficulty recalling objects. Cranial nerves II-XII intact, full muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes 2+ bilaterally, Babinski sign absent, sensation to pinprick and light touch normal.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the best management strategy for a patient with right knee pain and no significant findings on physical .

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with right knee pain over the last 3 weeks, which is moderate in severity and worsens with activities involving knee bending.

Secondary_Symptoms: Discomfort during physical activity, especially running and squatting

Knee_.Findings: Localized pain in the right anterior knee without erythema, swelling, or crepitations; no movement limitations.

Objective_for_Doctor: Provide advice on antiepileptic therapy adjustments for a patient considering pregnancy.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 5-year history of epilepsy with focal-onset motor seizures and is currently seizure-free on 50 mg of lamotrigine 3 times a day. She does not have concurrent illnesses and takes no other medications, except oral contraceptive pills.

Correct_Diagnosis: Recommend 5 mg of folic acid daily with no changes to antiepileptic therapy

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the cause of bloody vomitus and chest pain in a patient with a history of alcoholism.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the emergency department with a history of bloody vomitus. He is an alcoholic and has experienced similar symptoms before.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Sudden substernal chest pain and dysphagia
Secondary_Symptoms: Subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and supraclavicular areas

Physical_Exam.Findings: Subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and supraclavicular areas

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the infectious cause of fever, rash, abdominal pain, and vaginal discharge in a sexually active female patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with fever, rash, abdominal pain, and vaginal discharge for the past 3 days. The abdominal pain is moderate and cramping, localized to the suprapubic region. The rash is painless and not itchy. Associated symptoms include generalized muscle aches and vomiting. The patient has a history of chronic asthma managed medically, denies recent travel or sick contacts, and has been sexually active for the past year with a single partner while using oral contraceptive pills.

Abdominal_.Findings: Moderate tenderness to palpation of the suprapubic and lower right quadrants, no rebound or guarding, abdomen non-distended, no hepatosplenomegaly.

Pelvic_.Findings: Purulent vaginal discharge

Rash.Description: Diffuse erythematous desquamating maculopapular rash over the lower abdomen and inner thighs

Correct_Diagnosis: Gram-positive cocci in clusters producing superantigens

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of sudden change in responsiveness and back/flank pain post-cardiac catheterization.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a history of obesity, diabetes, and hypertension. He consumes 5 alcoholic drinks nightly and has a 40 pack-year smoking history. Works as a truck driver and leads a sedentary lifestyle. Recently underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting after presenting with crushing substernal chest pain.

Secondary_Symptoms: Tenderness over lumbar back and flanks

ECG.Findings: ST elevation in V2-V5 with reciprocal changes

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of fever, flank pain, and hematuria in a patient with a recent history of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 2-day history of fever, flank pain, and hematuria. He has chronic back pain and has been taking meloxicam for the past 2 weeks.

Secondary_Symptoms: Diffuse maculopapular rash over trunk and extremities

Skin_.Findings: Diffuse maculopapular rash over trunk and extremities

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the patient's mental state and determine the appropriate management after a manic episode.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presented to the emergency department after being found directing traffic at night. She reports having created a pooled queuing system for traffic management. She has a past medical history of depression and was started on an SSRI last week.

Physical_Exam.Findings: Deferred due to patient irritability

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of numbness, tingling, and muscle pain in a lactose intolerant man with a history of smoking.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is a software engineer who has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He occasionally drinks wine with dinner. He presents with numbness and tingling in his fingers and toes for the past month and severe calf pain at night.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Numbness and tingling in fingers and toes
Secondary_Symptoms: Tenderness in proximal muscles of upper and lower limbs

Musculoskeletal_.Findings: Tenderness in proximal muscles of upper and lower limbs

X-ray.Findings: Features of demineralization in lower limbs

Correct_Diagnosis: Low serum 25-OH D with low serum calcium levels

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of jaundice and fatigue in a patient with a history of pancreatitis and risk factors for liver disease.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with fatigue and weight loss over several weeks, losing seven pounds in the last month. His wife has noticed yellowing of the eyes. He has a history of acute pancreatitis, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and obesity. He consumes two glasses of wine most nights and has a 30-pack-year smoking history.

General_.Findings: Icteric sclera, abdomen soft, non-distended, and without tenderness to palpation. Bowel sounds are present.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of dysphagia and chest pain in a patient with a history of AIDS.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with difficulty swallowing for the past few days and progressively worsening chest pain when swallowing solids or liquids. He works from home, has no recent sick contacts, and is currently not sexually active. His medical history includes AIDS, and current medications are emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir.

Oral_.Findings: Dry mouth with red mucosa, no distinct plaques or patches

Neck_.Findings: Supple neck with no masses or cervical lymphadenopathy

Endoscopy.Findings: Small white patches within the esophageal lumen

Biopsy.Findings: Microscopic appearance consistent with fungal infection

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of fatigue, weight gain, and depression in a middle-aged female patient with a significant psychosocial history.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with fatigue that began several months ago following her husband's suicide. She reports thoughts of joining her husband, excessive weakness, and a 15-pound weight gain over the last month. Her medical history includes joint pain, a recently resolved skin rash, obstructive sleep apnea, and metabolic syndrome. She takes ibuprofen and omeprazole as needed.

Secondary_Symptoms: 15-pound weight gain in the last month

General_.Findings: Overweight woman with an overall depressed affect. Cardiac exam shows normal rate and rhythm. Pulmonary exam reveals bilateral clear lung fields with good air movement.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of left flank pain and fever in a disoriented patient with a history of diabetes and smoking.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the emergency department after being found disoriented. Has diabetes and sleep apnea, both well controlled. Reports left flank pain and fever. Chart review indicates a 30-pack-year smoking history and approximately 20 pounds of weight loss since last visit.

Physical_Exam.Findings: Bulge in left scrotum

Ultrasound.Findings: Bilateral kidney stones

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a patient with acute gout exacerbation.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 1-day history of severe pain and swelling of the left great toe, with a history of similar episodes over the past 3 years. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her alcohol intake is 6 beers daily, and she is allergic to hydrochlorothiazide and glipizide. Current medications include amlodipine and metformin.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Severe pain and swelling of left great toe
Secondary_Symptoms: Erythema and warmth of the left first metatarsophalangeal joint
Tenderness of the left first metatarsophalangeal joint

Joint_.Findings: Erythema, warmth, and tenderness of the left first metatarsophalangeal joint with a nodule over the right elbow

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the risk of influenza contraction in an unvaccinated population during flu season.

Patient_Actor.Demographics: 4th grade class with 20 students in Salem, Massachusetts
Patient_Actor.History: Due to media coverage, none of the 20 students have been immunized against influenza this year. They remained healthy until the flu season.

Secondary_Symptoms: 2 students contracted influenza in the first week
3 more students in the second week
5 more students in the third week

Correct_Diagnosis: Risk of contracting influenza during the second week is 0.17

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and determine the cause of abdominal pain and associated symptoms in a 67-year-old male patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a month-long history of worsening abdominal pain, weight loss, and general fatigue. His past medical history includes obesity, diabetes, and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, insulin, and lisinopril. He is a current smoker and consumes approximately 3 alcoholic beverages daily.

Secondary_Symptoms: Tender palpable masses bilaterally along the lower extremity

Cardiac_.Findings: Within normal limits

Lower_Extremity_.Findings: Multiple tender palpable masses bilaterally that track linearly along the lower extremity

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the psychological and physical health of a 16-year-old boy with symptoms suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome and bullying.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents due to concerns from his parents about persistent poor performance at school, increased impulsivity, and difficulty making and keeping friends. He reports being bullied by classmates due to his high-pitched voice, thin build, and poor grades.

Physical_.Findings: Bilateral gynecomastia, sparse pubic hair, long limbs compared to trunk, small firm testes

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage foot sensory changes and muscular atrophy in a young adult.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with several months of foot sensory changes, difficulty distinguishing between different surfaces, and a couple of falls without preceding lightheadedness or palpitations. His family history is unknown due to adoption.

Secondary_Symptoms: Muscular atrophy in legs and feet
Decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick up to mid-calf

Neurological_.Findings: Leg and foot muscular atrophy, decreased strength and sensation in lower extremities, absent ankle jerk reflex, pes cavus deformity

Nerve_Conduction_Studies.Findings: Decreased conduction velocities in bilateral peroneal nerves

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of musculoskeletal pain and respiratory symptoms in a young male patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with increasing lower back and neck pain over the past 7 months, worsening in the morning and improving with physical activity (basketball). He has experienced shortness of breath during basketball for the past 2 months. He is sexually active with 2 female partners and uses condoms inconsistently.

Secondary_Symptoms: Shortness of breath while playing basketball
Limited range of motion in the back
Decreased chest expansion on full inspiration

Physical_.Findings: Tenderness over sacroiliac joints, limited range of motion in the back, clear lung auscultation, decreased chest expansion

Imaging.X-Ray Findings: Erosion and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints, loss of spinal lordosis

Correct_Diagnosis: Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of altered mental status and neurological signs following a fall and convulsions.

Patient_Actor.History: Admitted to the hospital after a fall, initially unresponsive but regained consciousness en route. Witnesses report convulsions lasting about 30 seconds after losing consciousness. Complains of intense headaches and nausea upon admission.

Secondary_Symptoms: Inability to fully abduct both eyes

Neurological_.Findings: Pupils round, equal, and poorly reactive; no signs of skull fracture; nuchal rigidity; positive Kernig sign; no papillary edema or retinal hemorrhages.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of muscle pains and elevated serum transaminases in a patient on hypolipidemic therapy.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with hypercholesterolemia and a significant family history of cardiac deaths and cardiovascular diseases. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and a BMI of 28 kg/m2. Total cholesterol is 255 mg/dL and LDL is more than 175 mg/dL. After lifestyle and dietary modifications, a hypolipidemic drug was prescribed.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the patient for potential genetic connective tissue disorders and associated complications.

Patient_Actor.History: Presenting for a normal check-up after not seeing a physician for ten years. Reports feeling well with no complaints.

Secondary_Symptoms: Long and tapered fingers and toes

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of dizziness, nausea, and hearing loss in a patient with a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with nausea and dizziness, unsure of the onset but states symptoms have been affecting him for a while. Initially experienced unsteadiness which progressed to a spinning sensation. Reports worsening hearing loss as noted by his wife, who has to repeat herself, especially on his right side. Past medical history includes hypertension, alcoholism, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications are aspirin, amlodipine, and fluticasone-salmeterol. He consumes red wine daily and smokes cigars on weekends.

Neurological_.Findings: Delayed horizontal nystagmus

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the likely infectious cause of the newborn's symptoms following premature delivery.

Patient_Actor.History: Delivered to a 27-year-old woman at 33 weeks' gestation. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, but the mother experienced a cold and sore throat 2 months prior to delivery, which resolved spontaneously.

Secondary_Symptoms: Jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae

Abdominal_.Findings: Hepatosplenomegaly

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of fatigue, weight loss, and joint pain in a 14-year-old girl with possible autoimmune involvement.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a 6-week history of fatigue, 3-kg weight loss, intermittent low-grade fevers, and recurrent episodes of pain in her left wrist and right knee. There is a family history of rheumatoid arthritis.

Secondary_Symptoms: Swollen and tender left wrist and right knee

Musculoskeletal_.Findings: Swollen and tender left wrist and right knee

Oral_.Findings: Several painless oral ulcers

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and determine the underlying cause of confusion and abdominal pain in a young patient with a recent history of gastrointestinal symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department with confusion that started earlier in the day. He had vomiting and diarrhea 3 days ago which resolved without medical intervention. Despite the resolution of nausea and vomiting, he continues to experience diffuse abdominal pain and decreased appetite. His past medical history is unremarkable, but there has been recent weight loss and increased thirst. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs, and is not sexually active.

Secondary_Symptoms: Tachypnea (respiratory rate 27/min with deep and rapid respiration)

Abdominal_.Findings: Diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding, rebound tenderness, or rigidity

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the causative organism of respiratory distress and fever in a 6-week-old infant.

Patient_Actor.History: Previously healthy infant presenting with fever, fatigue, dry cough, and poor feeding. Maternal history includes being a cystic fibrosis carrier.

Secondary_Symptoms: Decreased urine output (fewer diapers than usual)

Clinical_.Findings: Ill-appearing infant with nasal flaring, dry mucous membranes, intercostal and supraclavicular retractions, and expiratory wheezes on auscultation.

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the cause of dyspnea and chest pain in a patient with recent respiratory infection and signs of cardiac involvement.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 1-week history of progressively worsening dyspnea and intermittent chest pain that increases on inspiration, following an upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago.

Chest_X-Ray.Findings: Enlarged cardiac silhouette, prominent vascular markings in both lung fields, blunted costophrenic angles

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and manage a pregnant patient presenting with hypertension, thrombocytopenia, and seizure risk at 34 weeks gestation.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the emergency department at 34 weeks gestation with vague upper abdominal pain and nausea lasting for 2 weeks, along with persistent headache over the past several days.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Vague upper abdominal pain and nausea

Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the cause of the patient's symptoms following a fall, considering the history of frequent falls and delayed development.

Patient_Actor.History: Brought to the emergency department after a fall in the park. History of spontaneous frequent falls and delayed development, for which calcium and iron supplements were prescribed. On antibiotic therapy for an unremitting cough for the last 2 days.

Secondary_Symptoms: Red eyes with dilated, tortuous conjunctival blood vessels

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the underlying cause of sudden onset chest pain and associated joint swelling in a patient with a history of hypertension.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with sudden onset sharp, non-radiating chest pain that improves when sitting up and leaning forward. She denies fever, chills, or cough but reports swollen hands and wrists for the past 3 weeks. Medical history includes chronic hypertension and an appendectomy at age 12. Current medications are hydralazine and folic acid.

Secondary_Symptoms: Swollen and tender metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally
Mild distress, especially in the supine position

Joint_.Findings: Swollen and tender joints bilaterally

ECG.Findings: Diffuse ST elevations

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate anesthetic for a patient with alcoholic cirrhosis undergoing exploratory laparotomy after a high-speed motor vehicle collision.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of alcoholic cirrhosis and was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was brought to the emergency department 20 minutes post-accident.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Hypotension and labored breathing following trauma
Secondary_Symptoms: Ecchymoses over the trunk and abdomen

Physical_Exam.Findings: Ecchymoses over the trunk and abdomen

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the phase of embryonic lung development during which terminal bronchioles branch into respiratory bronchioles and further into alveolar ducts.

Patient_Actor.History: N/A

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the nephron segment affected by the diuretic used in a patient with congestive heart failure and recent electrolyte abnormalities.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has congestive heart failure and recently had his medication regimen adjusted to better control hypertension. Three weeks later, laboratory analysis shows decreased serum calcium and magnesium levels.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Electrolyte abnormalities (decreased serum calcium and magnesium)

Objective_for_Doctor: Understand the biochemical principles governing protein synthesis from mRNA sequences.

Patient_Actor.History: The researcher is investigating how mRNA codons encode information about proteins. He constructed a sequence of cytosine nucleotides and synthesized a string of prolines.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Inconsistent amino acid production from mRNA sequences
Secondary_Symptoms: Synthesis of proline from single nucleotide sequence
New amino acids produced from specific codon sequences

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the cause of progressive visual acuity loss and light sensitivity in a patient with a history of schizophrenia on long-term antipsychotic therapy.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 6-month history of progressive decrease in visual acuity and increased sensitivity to light. He has a past medical history of schizophrenia diagnosed in early adulthood, managed with antipsychotic medication for the past 20 years.

Secondary_Symptoms: Discrete brown deposits on the corneal epithelium

Ophthalmologic_.Findings: Discrete brown deposits on the corneal epithelium in both eyes

Objective_for_Doctor: Identify the cause of hypoxia in a patient following cholecystectomy.

Patient_Actor.History: Eight hours after undergoing a successful cholecystectomy, the patient developed shortness of breath.

Secondary_Symptoms: Oxygen saturation of 85% on room air

Cardiopulmonary_.Findings: Intercostal retractions and diminished breath sounds on the left side

Chest X-ray.Findings: Bilateral fluffy infiltrates and slight shift of cardiac silhouette to the left side

Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose potential complications following head trauma in a patient presenting with neurological symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department 3 hours after falling while mountain biking and hitting his head. Initially refused treatment but developed severe headache, nausea, and left leg weakness an hour ago.

Secondary_Symptoms: Left leg weakness (0/5 muscle strength in left knee and foot)
Bruise on the right side of the skull

Neurological_.Findings: Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation.

Objective_for_Doctor: Determine the appropriate management for a patient with gallbladder polyp and right upper quadrant abdominal discomfort.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal discomfort for the past couple of hours. She has had similar episodes in the past that subsided on their own.

Secondary_Symptoms: Normal physical  except for diffuse abdominal tenderness

Abdominal_.Findings: Diffuse tenderness of the abdomen

Ultrasound.Findings: 1.4 cm gallbladder polyp

Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the underlying condition causing motor difficulties and sensory loss in a pediatric patient.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 1-year history of swaying while walking, recent episodes of tripping, and trouble sitting/getting up from chairs and walking up stairs.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Swaying while walking and difficulty ambulating
Secondary_Symptoms: Significant loss of vibratory and proprioceptive sensation in extremities

Neurological_.Findings: Nystagmus, absent deep tendon reflexes

Musculoskeletal_.Findings: Pes cavus and slight kyphoscoliosis

Genetic_Testing.Findings: Significant expansion of the trinucleotide GAA on chromosome 9
